awd_titl_txt: Operator Algebras, Operator Theory and Free Probability Investigations
awd_abstract_narration:
Operators on Hilbert space provide the infinite-dimensional linear algebra framework for quantum mechanical observables. Since composition of two linear maps depends on which of the maps acts first, this is a noncommutative mathematics setting where noncommutative analogues of basic mathematical theories are being developed. The principal investigator will work in two directions involving Hilbert space operators, following recent realizations in his research. On one hand the exploration of invariant properties of n-tuples of operators under certain types of perturbations leads to the study of the rings of operators which almost commute in a certain sense with the n-tuple. Connections to operator theory questions as well as to noncommutative geometry in the sense of Alain Connes are appearing. The second direction is in the area of free probability, the most noncommutative among noncommutative probability settings. Free probability, which was initiated by the principal investigator, has important connections to random matrices, combinatorics and to operator algebras. Via the random matrix connection, there are applications to certain models in physics and to models of multiuser communication systems. Recently the principal investigator found that free probability has an extension to a so-called bifree probability theory, which is a fast developing new area, with many open problems and which will also be part of the free probability problems studied.     

In more detail, the principal investigator will explore on one hand commutants modulo normed ideals of operators, smaller than the ideal of compact operators, which constitute a new operator algebra framework for the study of normed ideal perturbations of operators and on the other hand the bifree extension of free probability, to systems with noncommuting left and right variables. The operator theory questions involve obstructions to quasicentral approximate units relative to a normed ideal with diverse relations to almost normal operators, entropy and supramenable groups. The commutants modulo normed ideals are Banach algebras with involution of operators on Hilbert space, which have unexpectedly many relations to C*-algebras, like in the appearance of C*-algebras which are coronas of non-C*-Banach-algebras.  The K-theory aspects of these algebras are also of interest, for instance they provide a new angle on results about invariance of absolutely continuous spectra under perturbations . On the side of free probability and of its bifree extension the emphasis will be on the analysis, while other researchers emphasize the combinatorics. Trace-class commutators of hermitian operators appear both in questions about commutants modulo normed ideals and in free and bifree probability, with the possibility of being a point where the two subjects meet. The principal investigator expects to attract young mathematicians to research in areas of his investigations and in particular to continue organizing conferences and seminars about free probability, which has many connections to other fields in mathematics and provides good training for young mathematicians.

por.por_cntn:
Composing two linear maps depends on the order in which this is done. In particular Hilbert space operators, that underlie quantum mechanics, are a noncommutative mathematical framework. I have investigated two kinds of problems. On one hand I have studied normed ideal perturbations of n-tuples of Hilbert space operators and the related algebras of operators that commute mod a normed ideal with a given n-tuple of operators. These normed ideals are classes of operators on infinite dimensional Hilbert spaces that play the role of infinitesimals in the perspective  of Alain Connes' noncommutative geometry. The other questions I studied were noncommutative probability questions, especially free probability, which was initiated by myself and which exhibits the highest degree of noncommutativity. Free probability has important connections to operator algebras, random matrices and combinatorics. A broader impact of free probability comes from the connections to random matrices, that has led to applications of free probability to certain models in physics and to models of multiuser communication systems.      



Since the Euler equations of a flow that preserves a Gaussian measure can be described in terms of random variables, I found that there is an analogue in free probability of these equations. I showed that there is also an analogue of vorticity that goes with these free probability Euler equations. Moreover I also took the first steps in finding noncommutative smoothness in which solutions can be defined.An intellectual merit of studies such as those on the free probability analogue of Euler equations is that they contribute to the development of the kind of noncommutative analysis techniques for free probability questions, which are important for both the operator algebra and random matrix applications.   In another direction in noncommutative probability where the independence of noncommutative random variables is the so-called Boolean independence, together with Jorge Garza Vargas I studied the corresponding noncommutative extreme value laws and classified these.                                                                                    

In my work on normed ideal perturbations of n-tuples of operators an important development has been the realization that my approach can be extended to hybrid normed ideal perturbations, That is to perturbations with different normed ideals for the perturbations of each of the components of the n-tuple. I was able to obtain in the case of n-tuples of commuting hermitian operators sharp results which are on a par with my earlier sharp results when the normed ideal is the same for all components. I have also obtained new results in the case where the joint spectrum of the n-tuple of commuting operators is restricted to being part of a certain Cantor-like self-similar fractal set. It has turned out that the exact formula for the quasicentral  modulus has an extension where an integer exponent is replaced by the Hausdorff dimension of the fractal and an integration with respect to Lebsegue measure is replaced by an integration with respect to the self-similar Hutchinson measure which is a Hausdorff measure in this case.  In the study of commutants mod normed ideals I have extended the results from the case of a singleton hermitian operator to a singleton unitary operator.


Before the lockdown due to the Covid 19 pandemic, I have been one of the organizers of several free probability conferences. I have also continued the probabilistic operator algebra seminar at UC Berkeley with the participation of Ian Charlesworth who is an NSF Postdoctoral Fellow associated with me and of Jorge Garza Vargas a graduate student co-advised by Nikhil Srivastava and myself. During the lockdown the seminar has been online and has had a much larger participation. An impact of these activities has been their contribution to the development of young mathematicians in free probability and operator algebras.
